conclusion: A ray arrives parallel to the axis OO' at a distance rho from it and crosses the outer spherical surface at point P.
The polar angle of the radius OP with respect to the axis is varphi = arcsin(rho/R').
The outward normal at P is along OP.
The incidence angle on the outer surface is i = varphi, sin i = rho/R'.
Using Snellâ€™s law, the refracted angle r is sin r = (1/sqrt(2))(rho/R').
The refracted ray lies in the plane containing OP and the axis due to concentric spherical surfaces.
The ray meets the inner surface at point Q and the incidence angle on the inner surface is j = varphi.
The critical angle for total internal reflection in glass is theta_c = arcsin(1/sqrt(2)) = 45 degrees.
To prevent light from leaving the inner surface, j must be greater than or equal to theta_c, leading to varphi >= 45 degrees.
Translating the angular condition into a radial one gives rho >= R.
An opaque circular plate blocks rays with rho < d.
To meet the condition, choose d = R.
The required radius of the circular light shield is d = R.
